column102: RequirementText

The FDIR shall maintain the operational condition of the Spacecraft by the correct, timely and unambiguous detection of equipment and software failures, errors and anomalies, and the recovery of such failures, errors and anomalies by automatic software action and/or hardware reconfiguration.
No single system failure or single operator error shall have critical or catastrophic consequences.
No combination of two independent system failures or operators errors shall have catastrophic consequences
Safety inhibits shall be independent, verifiable, stable and stay in a safe position even in case of energy failure
For each on-board function, there shall be at least one alternative configuration that can achieve the same function using different on-board units
A failure of one component (unit level) shall not cause failure of or damage to another component or subsystem
A failure of one instrument shall not cause failure of or damage to other instruments, as well as other subsystems
Usage of the nominal or redundant branches of one equipment shall not require changes in telecommands directed to the equipment. Exception can be allowed for direct device commands
Reconfiguration switch from redundant to nominal branch of one equipment shall not be done automatically
The activation of a redundant unit or functional path by on-board autonomy or ground shall not require a change of the configuration or operational status of another related unit or functional path

Any situation, failures or operational situations, which will not cause immediate loss of but may develop into a loss of the Spacecraft, shall be prevented by design or identified and eliminated by FDIR function
The FDIR shall implement a configurable filter mechanism on the monitored parameters to prevent triggering of actions based on single occurrence of anomalies (e.g. one spike)

The Spacecraft shall respond to on-board failures by autonomously switching to a redundant functional path. Where this can be accomplished without risk to Spacecraft safety, such switching shall enable the continuity of the mission timeline and performance
The design of the system shall allow the verification of a currently un-used unit health prior to his operational use
Where redundancy is employed, the design shall allow verification of the nominal and redundant item/function also when not in use
In case of anomalies or failures from which the Spacecraft cannot recover autonomously, the Spacecraft shall enter a Safe Mode to ensure Spacecraft and payload survival
The design of fault management systems shall be intrinsically fail-safe
Compliance to the fault tolerance requirements shall be verified by FMECA or by other suitable methods, which are subject to agreement with ESA
It shall be possible for the ground to enable and disable individual fault management system functions
The FDIR design shall be modular such that the ground segment can enable and disable parts of it in a graceful and consistent manner without having a detrimental effect on the overall system
The overall status of the enabled and disabled FDIR functions, inputs and action shall be available in telemetry upon request
Failure propagation between nominal and redundant functions has to be excluded by design
The FDIR design shall incorporate provisions to inhibit anomalously long thrustersï¿½ firings
On-board monitoring shall be the activity continuously ensuring that the on-board units under supervision are in an acceptable safe state.

All parameters used for autonomous operations (e.g. thresholds for limit checking or thresholds and biases for attitude control), including fault management, orbit and attitude control, etc., shall be updateable by telecommand and available in telemetry, without the need for low level OBSW patch TC and dump TM.
For anomalies that are not causing an immediate danger to the mission, a recovery procedure shall be used to attempt the recovery of the element before setting the status of the element as failed.
Any potential conflict between failure recovery activities and nominally on-going on-board commanding activities shall be identified and managed.
The FDIR shall be designed to ensure that response to any given failure is deterministic, repeatable and with a limited execution time.

The Spacecraft shall maintain a list of available and failed hardware updated by FDIR and Ground. This information shall be maintained across on-board computer reset and reconfiguration, and used by the on-board software to configure the Spacecraft.
Any selection of prime or redundant equipment shall be reversible.

The capability shall be provided for the Ground to allocate which of the redundant units are to be included in the nominal chain and which in the redundant chain upon the next system reconfiguration, also in the case of a processor restart.

At power up, restart and upon recovery from any power loss, the space segment electrical configuration (including all subsystems, units and instruments) shall be set into a known deterministic and reproducible state. This configuration shall not depend on the speed of the level of power becoming available.
All authorized combinations of prime and redundant equipment shall exhibit the same operational characteristics.
A single failure shall trigger a single FDIR action.
The management of anomalies/failures within a unit, subsystem or instrument shall be handled in a hierarchical manner, such that resolution is sought on the lowest possible level.
The Spacecraft FDIR shall handle instruments failures that are not handled within the instruments themselves.
Failures that cannot be handled at a given level shall be handed over to the next higher operational instance, the highest instance being the ground segment.
Failure detection, isolation and recovery activities performed on-board shall be reported in an unambiguous manner to the ground segment.

The failure detection functions at all levels shall be able to carry out consistency verification checks on redundant sensor readings whenever redundancy is available, before starting the recovery actions.

Where FDIR functions are based on several inputs (e.g. sensor readings, and unit status), which are independently tested to determine a failure condition, the capability shall be provided to enable and disable each such input by telecommand.
FDIR functions shall not react to inputs that are disabled.
All intelligent units shall perform regular self-checks, and shall report on failure detection.
Anomalies and autonomous actions shall be reported in event telemetry packets.
Telemetry indicating the cause of an on-board reconfiguration shall be available to the ground after the completion of the reconfiguration, also in the case of multiple reconfigurations.
It shall be possible through the analysis of event and telemetry packets to reconstruct the events causing each FDIR actions.
The system shall ensure that safety critical software (such as that involved in FDIR, for example) is protected from potential errors in less critical software.
The Euclid Spacecraft (excluding the VIS and NISP instruments) shall be designed to provide a reliability of higher than 0.94 over the total operational lifetime.
The Safe Mode shall maintain the safety of the Spacecraft minimizing the consumption of on-board resources and maximizing their generation.
The Safe Mode shall be activated automatically by the S/C after a major on-board failure affecting the mission objectives, the mission lifetime or the mission safety.
Individual instrument failures shall not lead to a "Safe Mode" of the Spacecraft.
Spacecraft Safe Mode shall not rely on instrument functions.
Upon entrance into Safe Mode the instruments shall be commanded off.
The Safe Mode shall ensure a two way communication link with the ground station when coverage is available for at least housekeeping telemetry data and commanding.
TM and TC rates available in Safe Mode shall be sufficient to enable Ground to troubleshoot the failure and to execute a recovery strategy.

In Safe Mode the Spacecraft shall start generating a minimum set of telemetry packets that allow unambiguous and rapid identification of the Safe Mode. The reason for the triggering of the Safe Mode and the history of the defined events occurred before and after the detection of the failure condition shall also be accessible in telemetry either directly or stored in memory areas that can be later dumped and reset by the ground.
It shall be possible to enter the Safe Mode by ground command. Exit from the Safe mode shall only be possible by ground command.
The Safe Mode shall not rely on any volatile memory (Random Access Memory or other) stored data.
Upon entry in the Safe Mode, the Mission Time-Line shall be discontinued. The TM format shall be switched to HK mode only.
Spacecraft Safe Mode shall ensure Spacecraft survival and payload safety autonomously from Ground for at least 20 days.
It shall be possible to enable / disable autonomous entry, and to force entry into Safe Mode by telecommand. Autonomous entry shall be enabled by default.
No nominal operation (including critical mission events) shall require neither inhibition of the Safe Mode or a forced entry into Safe Mode. Any deviations shall be agreed by ESA.

The Safe Mode design shall prevent common errors with the rest of the software, so that parameters that have been previously modified or common code errors can prevent the correct execution of the Safe Mode.

The Spacecraft shall be designed to obtain all the necessary attitudes and orbit accuracy to perform the commissioning and calibration before the start of the exploitation phase, without affecting the Spacecraft safety.

The AOCS shall autonomously prevent attitudes that affect mission safety or mission success. This conditions shall be prevented also in the case of single on-board failure, software failure or operator error.
During Science Operation, AOCS housekeeping telemetry shall be recorded at sufficient rate and highest possible accuracy to reconstruct the Spacecraft pointing during each dither exposure.
The AOCS shall be designed to comply with the mission design as described in [RD 5] including the worst case launcher separation conditions in angular rate with 100% margins.

For stability and robustness performance, the approach defined in [AD 49] shall be followed for all modes and for all mission phases. The controller design and tuning shall ensure control stability and robustness with the following margins: the gain margin is greater than 6 dB, the phase margin is greater than 30 deg, the peak sensitivity and complementary sensitivity function is lower than 6 dB.
The parameters of the orbit shall be controlled to the level of accuracy required by the mission with due allowance for error contributions from on-board and ground sources.
The AOCS shall ensure that in any circumstance the sunlight shall not enter a 10 degrees half-cone angle around the telescope LOS.

The AOCS shall ensure that all performance requirements are met taking into account all possible disturbances, the uncertainties and evolution of Spacecraft parameters, propulsion subsystem performances and sensors/actuator degradation throughout mission life.

The slew time associated to a slew amplitude of 0.8 degrees, performed with any combination of rotations, in both sequence and amplitude, around the three Spacecraft axis, shall be performed in less than 290 seconds including stabilisation time and it shall take into account all disturbances including moving parts of the Spacecraft.

The slew time associated to a dither step as specified in SRD-SUR-11 shall be performed in less than 60 seconds including stabilisation time and it shall take into account all disturbances including moving parts of the Spacecraft.

AOCS shall provide the capability to update in-flight under Ground request and without the need to go through safe mode or reboot, the AOCS tuneable parameters which includes non-exclusively: parameters required by AOCS sensors to provide their services, AOCS sensors and actuators alignment matrices, FDIR and mode transition thresholds, selection of nominal and redundant AOCS sensors and actuators, filter coefficients, control law gains, calibration data, and time-out durations.
AOCS shall provide the capability to accept immediate and time-tagged telecommands to perform attitude and orbit control manoeuvres.
The AOCS shall provide the capability for the Spacecraft to follow an attitude profile commanded by the ground.

Sufficient sensor information shall be available on request in telemetry in each of the Attitude & Orbit Control modes to allow the Ground to determine the Spacecraft attitude independently of the on-board system estimation process.
AOCS shall provide Housekeeping TM to allow the ground verification of the correct performance of the attitude and orbit control algorithms.
AOCS shall provide Housekeeping TM to allow the ground monitoring the configuration, health and operation status of the AOCS nominal and redundant system.
It shall be possible to access and diagnose all operating units without impacting the current mode.

After a failure, AOCS shall provide sufficient information to the ground to assess the AOCS health status automatically by telemetry (event) packet and upon ground command. AOCS must allow transmitting to the ground the data from nominal and hot redundant sensors in parallel without degrading the nominal operations.
It shall be possible for the Ground to command, via dedicated telecommands, every individual actuator.

The AOCS shall manage and perform the AOCS mode transitions. Transitions between modes are to be triggered either by: TC: on ground request or by on-board control procedure, AUTO: autonomously by a nominal (positive) condition, FDIR: after a failure detection

The AOCS shall have an on - board safety logic that checks the following conditions before any mode transition will be authorized for execution: Transitions between allowed pairs of modes shall be rejected, if the pre-condition for the destination mode is not satisfied, i.e. S/C rates are too high to enter into Science Mode; Reject inadvertent commanding of forbidden mode transitions; A table of allowed and forbidden mode transitions between all possible pairs of modes, including the relevant parameters that are necessary to determine the preconditions, shall be maintained on-board and shall be updatable by telecommand and available in telemetry.

In each AOCS mode, the following priority of commands shall be respected: an FDIR transition must have priority over a TC or an AUTO transition; a TC transition must have priority over an AUTO transition.
The AOCS design of the Safe Mode shall avoid common failure with the modes used for the nominal mission

The propulsion subsystem shall perform the following functional requirements: provide attitude control around three orthogonal axes during all mission phases after launcher separation; perform correction manoeuvres during the LEOP and Transfer Phase; perform orbital maintenance manoeuvres during the Science Operations Phase. and Safe Mode manoeuvres; desaturate reaction wheels (if equipped); and decommissioning.
The Spacecraft shall provide X band link capability for telemetry, telecommand and ranging functions
The Spacecrat shall provide K band link capability, in the frequency range between 25.5 to 27 GHz, for telemetry function.
The Spacecraft shall be able to simultaneously receive and demodulate telecommands, modulate and transmit the telemetry on both X and K bands, and transpond the ranging signal.
Simultaneous usage of X-Band and K-Band data shall be possible without interference.
The Spacecraft shall support the following modes for the uplink: carrier only; telecommand; ranging; simultaneous Telecommand and Ranging.
The Spacecraft shall support the following modes for the downlink: carrier only; telemetry; ranging; simultaneous Telemetry and Ranging
The Spacecraft shall support two way coherent range and Doppler capabilities.
The Spacecraft shall have two independent hot-redundant receivers, both of capable of receiving uplink signals from ground at any time, independently from the Spacecraft antennas configuration.
Both the Spacecraft receivers shall send the demodulated ground signals to both telecommand decoders at the same time.
It shall be possible to operate the TT&C sub-system in coherent and non-coherent mode and this mode shall be selectable via telecommand.
The configuration shall be such that both receivers can receive and both decoders can decode simultaneously.
On-board switch off of the receivers and telecommand decoders shall not be possible.
The transmitters shall be able to receive the telemetry stream from nominal and redundant CDMUs.
The X-Band sub-system shall provide the required telecommand, telemetry and ranging capabilities at maximum distance from the Earth and in any Spacecraft attitude.
The K-Band sub-system shall provide the required telemetry at maximum distance from the Earth.
The stored housekeeping data shall be downlinked with the K band TM link as files. The real time housekeeping data shall be downlinked with the X band TM link.
The system shall be designed for a daily contact of 4 hours .
The system shall be able to transmit to ground 24 hours science and housekeeping data as well as receive the daily commands in a 3.5 hours daily communication window.
During all phases, the Spacecraft shall support an uplink TC rate of at least 4 kbps from the ground station, at any Spacecraft attitude, up to the maximum Earth-Spacecraft distance.
During all phases, the Spacecraft shall support a low-rate downlink TM data rate of at least 2 kbps to the ground station, at any Spacecraft attitude, up to the maximum Earth-Spacecraft distance.

The system design shall be compatible with a K-band telemetry with the following data rates, excluding protocol overheads: 67.5 Mbit/s, and a lower one to provide at least 3 dB additional margin in the link budget
The system shall be compatible with a daily telemetry volume scientific data of 850 Gbits/day after payload science data compression before protocol overhead.
The system shall be compatible with a X-Band telemetry net rate of at least 26 kbps.
The payload science data downlink communications shall be performed in K-band.
For the purpose of link budget calculation in K-Band an elevation angle higher or equal to 20 deg shall be assumed.
For the purpose of link budget calculation in X-Band an elevation angle higher or equal to 5 deg shall be assumed.
For the purpose of link budget calculation in K-Band, the availability of the link shall be higher than 95%.
Science Data, payload HK data and SVM HK data shall be transmitted in different virtual channels.
The Spacecraft shall support TC uplink rates of up to 64 kbit/s.
Two independent command Receiver/Decoder chains shall be provided and be separately accessible by designation of two different TC Virtual Channel.
The Spacecraft shall have hot-redundant telecommand decoding chains.
On-board switch off of the receivers and decoders shall not be possible.

Capability shall be implemented to transmit a group of selected housekeeping parameters also in case of unavailability of all on-board computers. The parameters contained in this hardware generated telemetry stream shall be selected in the design phase to allow ground control to assess the status of essential Spacecraft items. The telemetry stream is defined as ï¿½Essential Telemetryï¿½
Capability shall be provided to issue high priority commands (pulse and/or register load commands with only hardware support) to configure fundamental Spacecraft items
The delay from valid receipt of high priority commands and their execution shall be less than 2 seconds.
The delay from valid receipt to the time of execution of real time commands shall be less than 4 seconds.
The Spacecraft design shall provide the capability to handle hazardous telecommands.
Hazardous TC shall be used for the implementation of critical functions or actions that can endanger the Spacecraft if executed un-intentionally.
Hazardous commands shall be executed only upon reception of two independent telecommands, the arm TC and the fire TC.
The validity of the arm part of each hazardous command shall have a limited time life, expiring after a selected time interval has elapsed since its reception on board.
Capability shall be provided to store time-tagged commands to allow autonomous delayed execution.
The time specification of a time-tagged TC shall have a resolution of at least 250 ms.
The definition of the release instant of each time-tag TC shall be related to the Spacecraft Elapsed Time code pattern.
Vital Spacecraft health functions (e.g. primary bus current and voltage, propellant tank pressure, etc.) shall be monitored with redundant telemetry parameters.
The delay from the expiration time of a time-tag TC and its execution shall be less than one second.
Software residing in the same processor shall be developed using the same development environment to ease the maintenance and simplify compatibility.
The on-board SW shall be structured such that modifications to any individual code module have minimum impact on other modules.
On-board software shall be stored on non-volatile memory and executed in RAM.
At power ON, the boot-up sequence shall autonomously start and bring the Spacecraft to a safe configuration (power, thermal, pointing and communication).
At boot-up the software shall perform an integrity test of processor, memory and interfaces. The result shall be stored on-board and available to ground as part of hardware telemetry.
The software shall be designed to support electrical and functional test of a partially integrated Spacecraft.
On-board Software shall be protected against infinite loops, computational errors and possible lock ups resulting from an undetected hardware failure.
The Contractor shall demonstrate that the software can be scheduled under all circumstances including mission worst case and nominal scenarios to be agreed with ESA.
Starting or stopping processes shall not affect the execution or performance of other running processes.
Following a reboot or reconfiguration, ground shall be able to access all the necessary information to understand the sequence of event that lead to this condition.
All on-board software shall be re-programmable on ground and in orbit without any restriction with the exception of PROMs.
It shall be possible to temporarily and/or permanently patch the OBS image loaded on-board, independently of the Spacecraft status (including a software malfunction).
After a patch, it shall be always possible to revert to the previous software version on-board without the need to upload any other patch.
The software stored in non-volatile memory shall be protected from inadvertent modification.
The Spacecraft shall support direct control by ground.
The Spacecraft shall support autonomous (without ground contact) operations according to a mission timeline uploaded from ground.
The Spacecraft shall support rescheduling of planned events in the mission timeline by ground.
The Spacecraft shall support interruption of the mission timeline execution by ground command.
Phases when the Spacecraft needs a continuous contact with the Ground Control shall be limited to part of LEOP and transfer and shall be explicitly agreed by the Agency.
With the exclusion of selected parts of the LEOP, the Spacecraft shall be able to operate nominally, which includes performing routine science operations, without ground contact for at least 3 days.
For design and analysis purposes, it shall be assumed to have an average of 2 safe mode events per year, with an average duration of 2 days per event.
The Spacecraft shall provide mechanisms to avoid or recover from any conflict that can arise from the execution of on-board autonomous actions and Ground scheduled commands.
The space segment shall provide telemetry visibility of its internal status, and configuration, in sufficient time to allow adequate response by ground in case of contingencies.
The control functions (telecommands) provided at each level of the design hierarchy shall be capable of achieving the mission objectives under all specified circumstances.
The allocation of budgets for on-board resources shall provide specified spare capacities for each subsystem and each payload.

The capability shall be provided to determine at any point in the mission the remaining on-board resources that impact on mission lifetime. This shall be done by on-board logging and storing in non-volatile memory of the required parameters.
The telemetry shall provide unambiguous identification of the modes and mode transitions.
The modes of the Spacecraft and its payload, subsystems and units shall be clearly identified in terms of both hardware and software.

The Spacecraft shall have the knowledge of the actual health status of all the hardware units required for any mode start. This information shall be maintained by the on-board fault management function, updateable by telecommand and available in telemetry.
All modes shall be defined such that, for any logical unit used in this mode, any combination of physical units shall be possible.

On-board safety logic shall be available to prevent inadvertent commanding of forbidden mode transitions. The table of allowed and forbidden mode transitions between all possible pairs of modes shall be updateable by telecommand and available in telemetry.

It shall be possible to command the Spacecraft or any subsystem or instrument into each of the pre-defined Spacecraft modes by means of a single telecommand function (possibly by initiating a high level On-Board Control Procedure via telecommand).This includes Safe Mode.
It shall be possible to enable & disable Safe Mode Entry by hazardous Telecommand.
The Spacecraft shall not require any TM monitoring or TC commanding from Ground during the launch phase.
The Spacecraft shall record on-board all engineering data produced during the ascent and initial post-separation phase, for later dump to ground.
All mission phases shall be compatible with the available bandwidth for telemetry downlink.

During all mission phases (including LEOP and transfer to L2) there shall be no requirement for the MOC to send telecommands in nominal or contingency cases with a response time of less than 5 minutes, including the round trip of the signal.
Situations in which the MOC is expected to react within a short time (< 30 minutes during S/C coverage) shall be well identified and agreed by ESA.

Situations in which the MOC is required to react within a short time (< 30 minutes during S/C coverage) shall be unambiguously recognisable in the telemetry available to the MOC, without the need for complex processing (such as historical data processing).
The Spacecraft shall always be able to process a continuous uplink of telecommand packets at the highest nominal uplink rate.
HK Telemetry shall be continuously generated and recorded in all modes of operations, including Safe Mode.
Telecommands shall be available to command all on-board equipment and functions under all nominal and foreseen contingency conditions.

No single command function executed at the wrong time or in the wrong configuration or sequence, shall lead to a loss of mission. Execution of hazardous functions shall be implemented by means of hazardous telecommands.

Functions for which the missed execution can lead to major mission degradation shall be agreed by ESA, and their execution shall be command-able by either of two telecommand, nominal and redundant, independently routed.
A telecommand packet shall contain one and only one telecommand function.
It shall be possible to command the Spacecraft or any subsystem or instrument into each of their pre-defined operation modes by means of a single telecommand.
It shall be possible to command all on-board devices individually from the ground.

A telecommand that does not conform to the packet telecommand standard and/or is not recognised as a valid telecommand for the Euclid S/C shall be rejected at the earliest possible stage in the on-board acceptance and execution process.
The on-board reception, processing and execution of telecommands shall not affect any other independent on-board process.

Changes to on-board data or software parameters shall be implemented via a dedicated telecommand and not via a multi-purpose memory load telecommand. It is acceptable to access (individually) all parameters via a single telecommand of each type using unique parameter IDs to access the parameters.
Readouts of loaded on-board data or software parameters shall be requested via a dedicated telecommand and not via a multi-purpose memory dump telecommand.
The telecommand history (including content) of on-board issued commands shall be kept on-board for interrogation (and/or deletion) by ground.
In order to be able to unambiguously identify the source of a Telecommand (e.g. the ground or a given on-board process), the source shall be explicitly indicated within the Telecommand itself.

All commands shall be available as source being the ground segment except when: A reaction time is required faster than TM/TC turnaround time for automatic loops or 5 min when operation action is required; Commanding is required even during ground link interruption; The commands (like AOCS commands) are a result of the processing of data acquired on-board which cannot be routed to ground and processed on ground within the required time constraints. Input data and resulting commands shall be telemetered to ground; The commands are originated at ground but have to be updated and processed with on-board generated real-time parameters; The commands are generated on-board e.g. by OBCP

The ground shall be provided throughout the mission with the data, in raw form, required for the execution and analysis of all nominal operations and foreseen contingency operations for the Spacecraft subsystems and instruments. These data shall be contained in non-science data packets.
For any ground re-action, the availability of telemetry information shall be compatible with the required response times.
The Spacecraft housekeeping data shall provide the instantaneous and complete status and configuration of the Spacecraft and instruments at any time without the need to rely on the command history.

Telemetry shall be provided to allow complete and unambiguous verification of acceptance and execution of all telecommands sent from any source (sent from ground for immediate, delayed or time-tagged execution, and sent from on-board applications).
Telemetry shall always be provided to unambiguously identify the conditions required for execution of all possible configuration dependent telecommands.

Status information in telemetry shall always be provided from direct measurements from operating units rather than from secondary effects. This is in particular essential for the status of all on-board relays.
All mission critical functions shall be observable by at least 2 independently obtained measurements.
All inputs to on-board autonomous processes, in particular On-Board Control Procedures, shall be accessible to the ground via telemetry.
Information to indicate all actions of operational significance taken by on-board software shall be available in telemetry.

Software status telemetry shall include all commandable parameters such as monitoring and control thresholds, software tables, flags, global variables used by On-Board Control Procedures, etc. It is acceptable to access all parameters via a single telecommand of each type using unique parameter IDs to access the parameters. The telemetry packet shall include the parameter ID as the first parameter after the data field header.
The values of telemetry parameters shall be self-contained.
The value of a telemetry parameter shall be transmitted in contiguous bits within one packet.

Event packets (also from the monitoring service) of significance to the safe operation of the S/C and negative telecommand acceptance reports (Acceptance, Progress and Execution Failure Reports) shall be stored regardless of the status of the mass memory function and the mass memory unit.
Any packet carrying measurement and performance information for a unit shall also contain the information necessary to determine the validity of the data, e.g. the unit status.
If it is necessary to define synthetic parameters on ground (i.e. parameters which are calculated/validated using other parameters), all the contributing parameters shall appear in the same packet.

All packets shall include the time field in the data field header, except the Spacecraft time packet and the idle packet. The packet time field shall record the S/C elapsed time at the moment of the packet creation.

Event packet counters shall be provided in minimal housekeeping telemetry, (in the data field) which permits the unambiguous identification of the number of event packets generated on-board per APID and per severity level.
Telemetry shall be provided to enable detection and diagnosis of any identified failure at least down to function or equipment level.
Where telemetry measurements are processed on-board, the unaltered (i.e. unprocessed) data shall also be available in the telemetry.
For elements in hot redundancy, telemetry shall be provided to enable an independent and unambiguous evaluation of the status of each chain.
For elements in redundancy, the loss or failure of one chain shall not prevent access to the telemetry of the other chain.
Telemetry parameters shall be sampled at a frequency ensuring that no information of operational significance, for all nominal and contingency operations, is lost.

Sampling sequences and frequencies shall be specified for all related parameters that are correlated or combined for the purposes of Spacecraft monitoring or performance evaluation to ensure that no information of operational significance is lost.
Over sampling of telemetry parameters shall be possible for all internal parameters up to the update frequency of the respective parameter.
Telemetry frames shall be downlinked over different virtual channels as specified in the Space-Ground ICD Vol. 2
Capability shall be provided to modify the allowed telemetry bandwidth allocation of each of the Spacecraft virtual channels.
It shall be possible to establish by analysis the original on-board sampling time of any Spacecraft status telemetry parameter appearing in the telemetry source packets.
The proper synchronisation of any on-board application or intelligent user to the SCET shall be monitored on-board.
It shall be possible to activate any provided diagnostic mode of a non-operating unit without interfering with the nominal operation of the Spacecraft.
No fault management function shall trigger on test data generated by a unit operating in test mode.
Entering a test mode shall not require (or imply) disabling of fault management functions.
The capability shall be provided to load and check redundant memory prior to operational utilization.

Failure detection algorithms shall avoid continuous production of the same anomaly report packet, if the same failure is detected within a number of monitoring cycles which is to be defined for each failure case.
Failure detection algorithms shall start generation of all support telemetry packets considered necessary for the Ground analysis of the failure.
In nominal Spacecraft modes, a fault management function disabled by ground shall remain disabled until re-enabled by ground.

It shall be possible to request by telecommand the definition of all implemented on-board surveillances. The generated reports shall include the identifier of the reported surveillances and their complete definition (parameter being monitored, thresholds applied, filters applied).
The local reconfiguration of on-board units or the switching between on-board functions shall not affect the status, configuration, or the proper operation of any other unrelated unit or function.
The capability shall be provided to trigger by Ground commanding any on-board FDIR reconfiguration activities to put the Spacecraft into a predefined safe state.
The number of different Safe Modes shall be minimised by Spacecraft design.
The transition to a Safe Mode once started shall not be interruptible.

A counter for the accumulated commanded ï¿½thruster-onï¿½ time/accumulated commanded impulses shall be available in telemetry for each thruster independently and be maintained in non-volatile memory for the whole mission.
Determination of remaining propellant masses shall be possible to accuracy either better than 1% of the propellant at launch or better than 10% of the propellant remaining, whatever is more accurate.

The capability shall be provided to save the operational context in non-volatile memory so that it can be restored if a processor is reset or temporarily switched off. The system shall be protected against the use of the context memory when this contains wrong or corrupted data.
The resources utilized by on-board software shall be included in housekeeping telemetry (e.g., central processor unit (CPU) usage and I/O usage).
The capability shall be provided to check that on-board software has been correctly uploaded before enabling it.
For each processor running on-board, it shall be possible to reboot the processor (i.e. restart the software without reconfiguring the processor) using a single hazardous telecommand.
Any communication between the Ground and an on-board software function or software task shall be effected by means of telecommand and telemetry source packets specifically designed for the purpose.
Whenever a memory corruption is detected by an error detection and correction mechanism, an event telemetry packet shall be generated.
Whenever an internal inconsistency is detected, an event telemetry packet shall be generated.
The event telemetry packets that are generated in the case of a failure shall indicate the type of the failure, its location and any additional information needed for failure diagnosis.
The software version shall be reported as part of the event telemetry packet reporting successful boot and in housekeeping telemetry.
